courses.name: Financial Survival
courses.description: Examines financial management issues needed to survive the critical college years-credit/credit cards, budgeting/planning, financial aid, loans, common financial mistakes, debt management, setting financial goals, effective use of financial resources.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Financial Planning Careers
courses.description: This course will provide the student with a broad, general introduction to careers in financial planning.  Through readings, introspection, discussions, and guest speakers, the student will develop an understanding of the field.

courses.name: Personal and Family Finance
courses.description: Individual and family finance, with particular emphasis on financial planning, savings, insurance, investments, taxes, use of credit, and financial aspects of housing. Math Reasoning Proficiency Course. Students who wish to pursue a Personal Financial Planning emphasis must earn a B- or better, in FINPLN 2183.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100  with grade of C- or above

courses.name: Consumer as Entrepreneur
courses.description: The American economic system and marketplace from both a consumer and an entrepreneurial perspective.

courses.name: Financial Counseling
courses.description: Practical course on client financial counseling.  Course emphasizes client money issues including budgeting, credit, debt management, bankruptcy and other issues.  Students also will learn counseling strategies and communication skills to motivate clients to change negative behaviors and/or adopt positive behaviors.
courses.hours: 3Prerequisites or Corequisites: FINPLN 2183 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Financial Planning: Computer Applications
courses.description: Development of expertise in analyzing and understanding family financial case situations.  Applications include the use of leading financial planning software, as will as applications with spreadsheets.

courses.name: Financial Planning: Real Estate
courses.description: Family housing and real estate investments as components of the family's quality of life and asset portfolio.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 3283; ECONOM 1014 and ECONOM 1015; STAT 1300 or STAT 2500

courses.name: Problems in Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Supervised and independent work.

courses.name: Sales Management
courses.description: Prepares students to enter financial service occupations dependent upon sales and sales management.  Attention given to skill development, evaluation of current and best practices.
courses.prerequisites: junior standing; acceptance into professional program; FINPLN 2183

courses.name: Tax Planning
courses.description: Principles, current law and practice of income taxation and its impact on personal financial planning for individuals, couples and families in their roles as investors, employees, and business owners.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 2183, FINPLN 3283 or instructor's consent.  Not available to Pre-Personal Financial Planning majors

courses.name: Community Agencies and Volunteerism
courses.description: Service learning in a non-profit community social support agency. Examines economic role of non-profits and volunteerism. Students engage in service and evaluate experience in seminar. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 4187 or FINPLN 7187 or instructor's consent. Not available to Pre-Personal Financial Planning majors

courses.name: Financial Planning: Applied Tax Law
courses.description: This course trains students to become volunteer tax prepares and provides the opportunity to use their skills in a lab setting to prepare personal tax returns for U.S. citizens and resident aliens living in central Missouri.  The course also discusses tax law, especially as it applies to clients of the Volunteer Income Tax Assistance site.

courses.name: Topics in Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Recent Trends in Personal and Financial Planning
courses.description: For upper-class students who wish additional knowledge and understanding in specific subject matter areas.

courses.name: Assessing the American Dream
courses.description: A systems perspective examining ways choice and culture shape American levels and standards of living.  The impact of trends in personal and family values, technology, the economy, mass media and social movements on household resource management.

courses.name: Assessing the American Dream - Writing Intensive
courses.description: A systems perspective examining ways choice and culture shape American levels and standards of living.  The impact of trends in personal and family values, technology, the economy, mass media and social movements on household resource management.

courses.name: Financial Planning: Risk Management
courses.description: Analysis of family financial risks and conservation of family assets via risk management, with primary focus on personal lines of insurance.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 3283; ECONOM 1014 and ECONOM 1015; STAT 1300 or STAT 2500.  Not available to Pre-Personal Financial Planning majors

courses.name: Financial Planning: Investment Management
courses.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7383). Introduction to investment for family financial planning.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 2183 and 3283; STAT 1300 or STAT 2500.  Not available to Pre-Personal Financial Planning majors

courses.name: Financial Planning: Employee Benefits and Retirement Planning
courses.description: Fundamentals of employee benefits and retirement planning. Consideration of options via government, employer, financial markets. Special circumstances of women, part-time, and contingent workers considered.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 4382, FINPLN 4383.  Not available to Pre-Personal Financial Planning majors

courses.name: Consumer and Household Economics
courses.description: Economic theory of consumer and household behavior, focusing on rationality, uncertainty, optimal search, heuristics, interactive decisions and considering implications for financial decision making and policy analysis.

courses.name: Effective Consumer Decision-Making
courses.description: Theory, concepts, principles underlying consumer decision-making, including rationality, uncertainty, optimal search, heuristics, interactive decisions; strategies for their application in the marketplace.

courses.name: Financial Planning: Capstone
courses.description: The course emphasizes the use of analytical tools to develop effective financial plans for individuals and households.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 4187, FINPLN 4382, FINPLN 4383 or instructor's consent.  Not available to Pre-Personal Financial Planning majors

courses.name: Financial Planning: Estate and Gift Planning
courses.description: Fundamentals, practical problems and solutions in basic estate and gift planning, business succession planning, and taxation issues.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 4382 and FINPLN 4383 or instructor's consent.  Not available to Pre-Personal Financial Planning majors

courses.name: Topics in Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Financial Success
courses.description: Examines financial management issues needed to survive the critical post-college years - managing educational debt; after-school budgeting; auto, health, and other forms of insurance; retirement planning and other investment issues; setting financial goals; effective use of financial resources. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Readings in Personal Financial Planning
courses.prerequisites: restricted to Personal Financial Planning Majors only

courses.name: Topics in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Teaching Personal Finance Literacy
courses.description: (same as LTC_V 7083). Principles and practices of teaching personal finance with particular emphasis on income, money management, spending and credit, and savings and investing.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Supervised independent work related to household economics and finance.

courses.name: Seminar in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Reports and discussion of recent research and practice in household economics and finance.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Issues and concepts related to the financial planning process, including determination of financial goals and expectations and analysis and evaluation of personal and family financial data with emphasis on savings, insurance, investments, taxes, credit and financial aspects of housing.

courses.name: Financial Planning
courses.description: Principles, current law and practice of income taxation and its impact on personal financial planning for individuals, couples and families in their roles as investors, employees, and business owners.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 2183, FINPLN 3283, ACCTCY 2010 or equivalent or instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Financial Counseling
courses.description: Students will learn client-centered financial counseling.  Includes development of interviewing techniques, focus on personality strengths and weaknesses, creation of the sales process, and the role of technology in counseling.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Recent Trends in Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: For upper-class and graduate students who wish additional knowledge and understanding in specific subject matter areas.

courses.name: Assessing the American Dream
courses.description: A systems perspective examining ways choice and culture shape American levels and standards of living.  The impact of trends in personal and family values, technology the economy, mass media and social movements on household resource management.

courses.name: Financial Planning: Risk Management
courses.description: Analysis of family financial risks and conservation of family assets via risk management, with primary focus on personal lines of insurance.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 3283; 5-6 hours of Economics; STAT 1300 or STAT 2500

courses.name: Financial Planning: Investment Management
courses.description: Management of family financial investments.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 3283; 5-6 hours of Economics; STAT 1300 or STAT 2500

courses.name: Financial Planning: Employee Benefits and Retirement Planning
courses.description: Fundamentals of employee benefits and retirement planning. Consideration of options via government, employer, financial markets. Special circumstances of women, part-time, and contingent workers considered.

courses.name: Consumer and Household Economics II
courses.description: (cross-leveled with FINPLN 7387). Economic theory of consumer and household behavior, focusing on rationality, uncertainty, optimal search, heuristics, interactive decisions and considering implications for financial decision making and policy analysis.

courses.name: Effective Consumer Decision-Making
courses.description: Theory, concepts, principles underlying consumer decision-making, including rationality, uncertainty, optimal search, heuristics, interactive decisions; strategies for their application in the marketplace.

courses.name: Financial Planning: Capstone
courses.description: The course emphasizes the use of analytical tools to develop effective financial plans for individuals and households.
courses.prerequisites: FINPLN 4187, FINPLN 4382, FINPLN 4383 or instructor's consent.  Not available to Pre-Personal Financial Planning majors

courses.name: Financial Planning: Estate and Gift Planning
courses.description: Fundamentals, practical problems and solutions in basic estate and gift planning, business succession planning, and taxation issues.

courses.name: Research Methods in Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Introduction to the scope, purpose and methods of research in consumer and family economics, with emphasis on economic survey methods.

courses.name: Personal Financial Issues of Older Adults
courses.description: (same as H_D_FS 7583).  Principles and practice of personal finance relevant to assessing and improving the financial security of older individuals.  Topics covered include sources of income, management of cash flow, credit use and abuse, risk exposure, investment management, housing, and financial planning.  Financial vulnerabilities of seniors will be explored.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: Bachelor or Master's degree in human services, social work, mental health, nursing physical rehabilitation or psychology; Must be enrolled in Graduate Certificate in Geriatric Care Management program

courses.name: Readings in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Readings in recent research in household economics and finance.

courses.name: Internship in Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Internship in Personal Financial Planning.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent; Restricted to Personal Financial Planning Majors Only

courses.name: Topics in Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Problems in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Supervised independent work related to household economics and finance.

courses.name: Seminar in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Report and discussion of recent research and practice in household economics and finance.

courses.name: Master's Thesis Research in Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Independent research leading to thesis or dissertation. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Military Personal Financial Readiness
courses.description: Financial planning process applied to military personnel and their families.  Focus on service member status; financial readiness; record-keeping; management of cash flow, risk, credit and debt, savings, investments, tax, savings; education planning, retirement and estate planning.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Professional Practices in Financial Planning
courses.description: Practice management techniques for Financial Planners. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Family Systems
courses.description: Exploration of the family as a system within the broader context of society.

courses.name: Theories and Research in Personal Financial Planning I
courses.description: Course introduces students to the social science of family finances. Course covers the theories of family functioning, microeconomic theory related to family resource allocation decisions, the family as an economic unit, and the interaction of families and the economy. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Theories and Research in Personal Financial Planning II
courses.description: Course reviews theories and empirical research in household financial decision-making, drawing from macroeconomic theory, theories of household behavior, lifecycle hypothesis, behavioral economics and finance, theories of behavioral change and psychological theories of family well-being. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Housing and Real Estate
courses.description: The study of real estate as a component to household wealth.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: International Employee Benefits and Retirement Planning
courses.description: This course develops the theory and application of international employee benefits and retirement planning. Universal theory will be applied to analyze existing programs in an international context. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Financial Planning Case Studies
courses.description: The analysis and development of appropriate presentations for effective financial plans.

courses.name: International Estate and Gift Planning
courses.description: This course develops the theory and application of end of life planning in an international context.  Core estate planning education will prepare students to sit for the CFP exam, while addressing issues prevalent in other countries.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Applied Research in Household Economics and Planning
courses.description: Independent research not leading to a thesis. Report required. For students completing Master's in Personal Financial Planning.

courses.name: Family Economics
courses.description: Multidisciplinary study of research on families as economic units. Examines trends in family income, wealth, labor market participation, household production, distribution of household resources, use of public goods, and underground economy.

courses.name: Human Resource Development and Allocation
courses.description: Economic analysis of conditions, programs and policies related to development and use of human resources, with special reference to impact on families and households.

courses.name: Social Policy and the Family Economy
courses.description: Economic analysis of public programs that directly affect well-being of families: income maintenance, goods transfers, employment, housing, health, transportation, taxes, etc.; consideration of underlying philosophies, policy alternatives.

courses.name: Household Financial Decision Making
courses.description: This course provides a solid foundation for critical thinking and research on household financial decision making.  A selective but extensive review of normative and descriptive theories and empirical studies pertinent to household financial decision making is provided.  The focus is on developing a critical perspective in students that enables them to identify opportunities to advanced theory toward relevant applications through research on household financial decision making.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent.  A knowledge of intermediate micro economics, introductory statistics, and introductory differential calculus is assumed

courses.name: Personal Financial Planning Capstone
courses.description: Independent work on project approved by major advisor and CFP (R) Program Director.  For students completing Master's in Personal Financial Planning.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Readings in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Readings in recent research in household economics and finance.

courses.name: Topics in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Selected current topics in field of interest.

courses.name: Problems in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Supervised independent work related to household economics and finance.

courses.name: Seminar in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Report and discussion of recent research and practice in household economics and finance.

courses.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Independent research leading to thesis or dissertation. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Readings in Household Economics and Finance
courses.description: Readings in recent research in household economics and finance.
